newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian Broadcasting Corp Afternoon Update.
newsitem.headline: Australian Broadcasting Corp Afternoon Update.

text.p: MINISTER DEFENDS HIMSELF IN PARLIAMENT
In Parliament, Federal Small Business Minister, Geoff Prosser, has defended himself over claims he has breached the Ministerial code of conduct.
In a statement to the House, Mr Prosser set out his various West Australian business interests and strongly rejected claims they placed him in a conflict of interest.
The minister has been under sustained Opposition attack over claims he breached the code by maintaining his business interests, and contacting a local councillor about a proposed development.
Mr Prosser confirmed he spoke to a councillor about a development, proposal on one of his Bunbury properties, but said he didn't feel his conversation breached the code of conduct.
He said he categorically rejects any allegation he, at any time, has used his ministerial position for personal gain.
The minister also told the House that business arrangements he had in place prior to, and since becoming a minister are within the letter and the spirit of the Ministerial Guidelines.
REGULATION ALLOWING WORKERS TO BE UNFAIRLY SACKED OVERTURNED
The Senate has overturned a new Government regulation allowing small businesses to sack their workers unfairly.
The Government had proposed small business be exempted from the unfair dismissal laws.
The Opposition, Greens and Independents supported a Democrats move to disallow the regulation.
Democrats Senator Andrew Murray says the regulation breached the Government's election promise to provide a "fair go all round" for all employees and employers.
Senator Murray says the new rule would have harmed 1.6 million workers and fail to create a single job.
He says the exemption could also be detrimental to small business, as it could lead to sloppy management practices and higher labour costs.
VICTORIAN POLICE TO CRACKDOWN ON STREET BEGGING
Victorian police will next week begin a crackdown on street beggars, most of whom they say are taking money to supplement other income.
Codenamed "Operation Beggar", the blitz will involve undercover and uniform police on Melbourne's streets to coincide with the school holidays.
Superintendent Tony Warren, of Melbourne Central Police District, says begging is a growing problem across the city and suburbs.
Superintendent Warren says it's not unusual for beggars to earn $100 dollars a day and that most were drawing on other incomes.
NEW RESOURCE AND RESPITE CENTRES FOR CARERS
The Federal minister for Family Services says planned resource and respite centres for carers, will make carers' jobs easier to cope with, as well as helping those being cared for.
Judi Moylan says at least 56 respite centres for carers will be set up across Australia within the next few months.
Mrs Moylan says they will provide support for carers to gain access to respite services when they need them.
She says there are thousands of carers in the community, and sometimes they just need a little reassurance, assistance or respite to carry out their role effectively.
The minster also launched a toll-free telephone number for carers to contact Carer Resource Centres in each capital city, which will provide information, access and links to the regional services.
COMIC BOOK LAUNCHED TO COMBAT RACIAL ABUSE IN SCHOOLS
A comic book has been launched today in a bid to combat racial abuse in schools.
Called "Takin' A Stand" the comic tells the story of an Australian born Vietnamese boy dealing with racial abuse and bullying at school.
While it has received a positive response, the South Australian Education Department has expressed concern about its references to Asians as "gooks", "slopes" and "crims".
But Human Right's Commissioner Zita Antonios says those concerns are ignorant.
Ms Antonios says the Commission worked very closely with young people in developing the publication, and they made it very clear that the comic had to "tell it like it is" to be realistic.
The comic was launched at a Sydney high school where 80 per cent of students come from non-english speaking backgrounds, and where racial problems are vitually non-existent.
It will be distributed to schools and TAFE colleges throughout the country.
WA PARLIAMENT TOLD 22 TEACHER SACKED FOR IMPROPER SEXUAL CONDUCT
The West Australian Parliament has been told 22 school teachers have been sacked in the past year for improper sexual conduct.

Education Minister, Colin Barnett, says the teachers were dismissed under the first stage of a review of all Education Department personnal files to prevent paedophilia and child abuse in Government schools.
Another three people were denied employment as teachers because of their record of abuse against children.

Mr Barnett says the review is currently examining 58,000 files, but 330 were identified as a priority because they included teachers with criminal records of sexual offence or unprofessional behaviour.
Mr Barnett says the review will examine allegations of unprofessional behaviour by teachers stretching back 10 years, and in future teachers will need police clearance before being employed.
SEARCH CONTINUES FOR MISSING CHILD AT MOE
In eastern Victoria, police divers will search a dam near the Moe rubbish tip, as the hunt for Jaidyn Leskie continues.
The boy's father, Brett Leskie, has arrived at the scene, and is being briefed by Homicide detectives.
Earlier police seized the car of the man who was babysitting Jaidyn on the night he disappeared.
It's been brought to Melbourne for extensive forensic testing.
And police are still sifting through rubbish at the tip, in the hope of finding clues to Jaidyn's whereabouts.
Search co-ordinator, Senior Constable Oscar Astson, says members are being forced to wear masks because of the revolting conditions.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
